36ef45d6b523e6527-min.en-US.js"},"squarespace-events-collection":{"css":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/styles-compressed/events-collection-a0cc7f57176bc63d87bc9f4149fada5a-min.css","js":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/scripts-compressed/events-collection-394a4faf8325ee70d19dd-min.en-US.js"},"squarespace-form-rendering-utils":{"js":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/scripts-compressed/form-rendering-utils-19bfb22ef23ec168a9bb6-min.en-US.js"},"squarespace-forms":{"css":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/styles-compressed/forms-d21f3e517c32f4caba9f220beea0666d-min.css","js":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/scripts-compressed/forms-ecdf1f62c581306e41557-min.en-US.js"},"squarespace-gallery-collection-list":{"css":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/styles-compressed/gallery-collection-list-d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e-min.css","js":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/scripts-compressed/gallery-collection-list-e23ee315df466f1dba9ec-min.en-US.js"},"squarespace-image-zoom":{"css":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/styles-compressed/image-zoom-72b0ab7796582588032aa6472e2e2f14-min.css","js":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/scripts-compressed/image-zoom-5a660e03e667b16c7a076-min.en-US.js"},"squarespace-pinterest":{"css":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/styles-compressed/pinterest-d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e-min.css","js":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/scripts-compressed/pinterest-4725f00d98ee2610ca950-min.en-US.js"},"squarespace-popup-overlay":{"css":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/styles-compressed/popup-overlay-e984c5797664760d617b07bce15392a1-min.css","js":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/scripts-compressed/popup-overlay-ecc6e11af2a74c0ea570e-min.en-US.js"},"squarespace-product-quick-view":{"css":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/styles-compressed/product-quick-view-3fa8fd4df0755e7a7878e60166ca3d61-min.css","js":"//assets.squarespace.com/universal/scripts-compressed/product-quick-view-08656cc21c6892715c7d8-min.en-US.js"},"squaresp div.p: COVID-19 Updates

We will email, call, and send mail (when possible) to all families regarding any updates or communications. Please note that in these unprecedented times, new information is coming quickly and we are working to make and communicate decisions as quickly as we can. Please read the latest post for the most up-to-date information. You can find a log of current and historical communications below:

As you may have heard already, Governor Tim Walz announced on Thursday, April 23rd that all Minnesota schools will remain closed and on distance learning plans for the remainder of the school year. Our district has been preparing for this as a precaution. We have schedules and processes in place to continue to teach and serve students through the last day of the school year (June 5th). Unfortunately, there are several events that we will have to change and cancel.

As part of the Governor’s Executive Order, St. Paul City Primary & Middle schools and River's Edge Academy will be closed on Friday, May 1, and Monday, May 4, for staff to prepare for Distance Learning through the end of the year.

We have made the difficult, but necessary, decision to cancel Graduation. We are committed to honoring individual Seniors and we will celebrate their accomplishments in other ways this Spring. Traditions are important at REA: we will still do final beads, Crew beads, and a Senior class portrait for the lobby. We will provide a free cap and tassel for all Seniors. We will take a picture of Seniors with their cap, gown and diploma for the Class of 2020 photo in the front lobby!
A virtual Senior and year end Celebration will happen on June 5th at 11am. Parents, please join your student!

li.p: Dr. Meg Cavalier will read Oh the Places You’ll Go to the Senior class.
Seniors will submit superlatives for their class online which will be announced during the senior celebration.
Seniors will present a bead to one of their peers on the call and via email. We will make sure the bead and message are delivered next school year!
Crew leaders will present beads to their Seniors.
Appreciations will be shared!
The 2019-2020 Slideshow will be presented.

div.p: We will communicate details on our alternative graduation ceremony and more as we gain more direction from the Governor. The staff and I are committed to providing a special experience for each graduate!

St. Paul Public Schools continues to offer free weekly meals to our students and their families. Please remember to practice social distancing when picking up meals. While REA families are welcome to pick up at the locations listed below, we are not eligible for Home Delivery. Visit www.spps.org/ns for more information.
Meals will be available for pick up from 10am-12pm (or while supplies last) on Fridays at the following sites.

li.p: Harding Senior High School (1540 6th St. E.)
Johnson Senior High School (1349 Arcade St.)
Chelsea Heights Elementary (1557 Huron St.)
Cherokee Heights Elementary (694 S. Charlton St.)

div.p: A reminder that students are currently taking one Block class and two electives during this time. We are currently in the middle of the Block 2 Distance Learning Term.

Grading will be done on a pass-fail basis while distance learning is in effect. In order to pass, students must meet the minimum requirements of the class and maintain consistent communication with staff members, including their teacher for the scheduled course, the Student Support Specialist, and admin (when relevant). In-progress and posted grades are available on Infinite Campus. If you need assistance logging in to Infinite Campus, please contact Ava Buchanan at abuchanan@reamn.org or 651-225-9177 x3006.
Attendance will be recorded based on direct communication with staff and interaction with coursework. The following will count toward a positive attendance mark (equivalent to present):

li.p: Calling or emailing a teacher or other staff member member.
Participating in a video/voice meeting with a teacher.
Interacting with course materials on Google Classroom.
Completion of assigned coursework through Google Classroom at regularly assigned intervals.

div.p: Staff have been and will continue to reach out regularly to check in on student progress via email and phone. Students are expected to return correspondence in a timely fashion. If students have not been in touch for two days in a row, REA will reach out to parents to alert them of this absence.
We are excited for distance learning to begin on Monday, April 6. The purpose of this letter is to provide you more information on our process for distributing materials.
On Monday April 6, our school buses will be driving to each of your homes and dropping off learning materials. The following will be included in this material drop-off:

li.p: Learning Packets: Your children’s teachers have put together work for the next 8 weeks.

Resource bags: We have created bags of materials for you which will include pencils, paper, crayons, scissors, glue, dice, and playing cards. These learning tools will support the tasks that teachers have designed.
Books: We will be loaning every family a bag of books for your children to read each day. Think of this like a mobile library!

div.p: We have designed bus routes so that they stop at your homes and not at a corner. Each bus will be staffed by two SPCS employees. The routes will begin at 11am. You will find your specific drop-off time included in this letter. One of the staff members on the bus will call you when the bus is 15 minutes away from your home so you can be on the lookout.

All materials were gathered and organized using the most sanitary process possible. In addition, all materials have been resting in our Primary School gym for over a week ensuring that all germs have dissipated. Our employees will be wearing rubber gloves when they deliver your materials. When you talk with them on the phone, be sure to indicate if you would like them to leave materials at your doorstop or if they should ring your doorbell and hand you the materials in person. Your health and safety remain a top priority!
If you have any questions, do not hesitate to give us a call – 651-925-3001. We look forward to working with you!

On March 25, Governor Walz announced that all schools will provide distance learning until at least April 30th. The purpose of this letter is to share with you our distance learning plan. Our entire staff has been preparing a plan that meets the academic and emotional needs of all of our students from a distance. While distance learning will never be as good as having your children in our classrooms each day, we have designed a strong plan to continue serving and supporting our students. Please read this letter carefully to ensure you understand the plan and your role as parents and guardians

On April 6, buses will drop off all primary school learning materials to your home. This will include work packets, a bag of learning materials (pencils, crayons, notebooks, etc.), and a bag of books. We are in the process of designing bus routes so that everyone will receive a direct stop at your home and not at a corner stop. You will receive a letter in the mail next week with the bus drop-off time. We will have a staff member riding the bus call you when the bus is within 20 minutes of your home.

You received a phone call from a St. Paul City School teacher this week to check-in with your family. To make it easier for you, we have assigned one teacher to be your family’s contact person for K-5th grade. This way you will not have to coordinate as many calls with different teachers should you have more than one student. The assigned teacher will help your child(ren) with their grade-level learning and communicate with you. Because of different requirements, Pre-K teachers will schedule a separate time to talk with your family. The learning plan includes daily activities in math and writing. K-1st grade students should also read 30 minutes per day and 2nd-8th grade students should read 60 minutes per day. Every child will be receiving regular phone calls from their teacher to provide continued support in reading, writing, and math.

On April 6th we will begin using the online platform Google Classroom for all middle school learning. Students may use a cellphone, tablet, or computer. This week, SPCS staff have encouraged students to log into their school email to access the google classrooms their teachers have created. Although students may do optional assignments now and over spring break, actual coursework resumes on April 6th via Google Classroom.

Students will be receiving further instructions from their individual teachers via google classroom. The initial expectation is that students will read 60 minutes/day on their own and work with a teacher who will help them with reading skills. Students will work on math with the support of Mr. Nelson and Ms. Joshi using a mix of assignments and online videos.

We understand that internet and technology devices are likely in families and have designed the assignments accordingly. We are here to work with you to support your family with online learning. If you experience any problems with online learning reach out to Ms. Reiling at 651-925-3060.

We will continue to meet the needs of all Special Education students. Your child’s special education teacher already contacted you to plan your daily schedule. Your child will receive the same accommodations and modifications that they typically receive. If your child has related services, this will be scheduled in addition to time with teachers. Examples include paraprofessionals, speech and language pathologists, and occupational therapists. Special education teachers will remain in contact with you and will hold IEP meetings over the phone according to need and yearly cycle.

English Learners will continue to receive instruction and support to develop their English skills. Students in the beginning stages of English development will receive daily instruction from an EL Specialist in grade-level content and in collaboration with a general education teacher. Your family’s assigned teacher will collaborate with EL Specialists to meet your child’s need for English language support. If you have any questions about English Learner support, please reach out to Mrs. Reissy at 651-925-3034.

At St. Paul City School, one of our fundamental promises is that every child will feel both safe and known. We are working hard to continue fulfilling this promise during this season of distance learning. We know how stressful it can feel to be stuck at home every day and isolated from peers. If you or your child are feeling stressed and need someone to talk to, please call our main office number at 651-925-3001 and you will be immediately directed to one of our social workers, counselors or Deans of students for support. Our full team of family liaisons and social workers remains available to support you in any way we can. Do not hesitate to reach out!

Attendance during distance learning will look different than it does during a normal school day but it is still very important. As a school, we are still required to take attendance and report it to the state. Please review the following guidelines so you understand how we will be approaching attendance.

li.p: A daily interaction with a teacher is required for a student to be marked present. An interaction may include a phone call, text, email, or engagement via an educational learning app.
Primary school students will receive at least two calls per week and on the days they do not receive a call will be expected to interact using one of the other options.
Middle school students working in Google Classroom each day counts as attendance.
Teachers will submit a referral to the social work team after 3 consecutive days of no contact.
There is no official attendance rule about what time of day the contact needs to occur.
If your child interacts with a special education teacher, an English Learner teacher, a paraprofessional, a social worker, or a related service provider this counts for the daily attendance.

div.p: These are unprecedented times. Each day we learn new information and have to adapt. While we have put an incredible amount of thought and heart into this plan, we are also mindful that things still might change. My promise to you is that we will be the best communicators we can be when changes happen. We ask that you will provide us your feedback along the way so we can continue to meet the needs of your children the very best we can.

Our staff has been working diligently the past two weeks to pull together a distance learning plan for our students. Distance learning for REA means that students will be able to complete all assignments from home using a phone, computer, or tablet. REA reached out last week to confirm availability of these technology tools at home; please call or email Esteban (erodriguezhefty@reamn.org or 651-225-9177x4016) as soon as possible if you do not have access to this technology.

We are waiting on further direction from the state, but we are prepared for classes to resume remotely (not at school) on March 30th, 2020. We anticipate that school may need to remain closed for a long period of time, and so have planned out a distance learning schedule for the remainder of the school year.

Students will be enrolled in their Quarter 4 Block classes one at a time for two week periods, as described in the schedule below. They will also select two Electives to take for Elective credit for the duration of the year. Crew leaders will work with students to assign electives during the week of March 30th.

div.class: image-block-outer-wrapper layout-caption-below design-layout-inline combination-animation-none individual-animation-none individual-text-animation-none

div.p: Grading will be done on a pass-fail basis while distance learning is in effect. In order to pass, students must meet the minimum requirements of the class and maintain consistent communication with staff members, including their teacher for the scheduled course, their SSS, and admin when relevant.

A Pass is equivalent to a 4/Exemplary, 3/Accomplished, or 2/Developing quality work. A Fail is equivalent to a 1/Incomplete quality work. If you have questions about a grade you received on an assignment, please communicate directly with the teacher of that course.

Attendance will be recorded based on direct communication with staff and interaction with coursework. Teachers will clarify minimum expectations for their class. The following will count toward a positive attendance mark (equivalent to present):

li.p: Calling or emailing a teacher or other staff member member. Please note that all staff will have remote phone numbers (included below).
Participating in a video/voice meeting with a teacher.
Interacting with course materials on Google Classroom.
Completion of assigned coursework through Google Classroom at regularly assigned intervals.

div.p: Staff will be reaching out regularly to check in on student progress via email and phone. Students are expected to return correspondence in a timely fashion. If students have not been in touch for two days in a row, REA will reach out to parents to alert them of this absence.

We ask that in these challenging times, families stay connected with us. As a school, we are able to help connect our families to many resources that you may not yet have access to. We are here to support you and your loved ones. REA will be reaching out regularly via phone and email communication and when we can through mail. Please check for these communications regularly.

On Sunday, March 15th Governor Walz declared a statewide closure of Minnesota schools to begin no later than March 18th. The purpose of this closure is to provide all schools the time needed to prepare for remote learning during a potential long term closure. Like many local school districts, St. Paul City Schools decided to close effective Monday, March 16th to allow for staff to best support safety for our students and staff and in order to begin immediately planning for next steps.

SPCS is working as a district and within each school site during the school closure to develop plans for providing consistent education to all students following spring break, regardless of whether we return to school buildings or are directed by the Governor to begin remote learning.

River’s Edge returns to classes March 30th. SPCS Primary and Middle return to classes April 6th. As directed by the Commissioner of Education under the Governor’s order, our staff are currently preparing for the possibility of distance learning if we are unable to return to in-person classes. All REA students will have the week of March 30-April 3 to connect with teachers and complete work to pass Quarter 3 classes. Details about class schedules, attendance, and grading for Quarter 4 will be provided to all students and families when spring break is over.

Beginning March 18, St. Paul Public Schools began meal distribution from their school bus stops or school sites. They will be offering these meals on three different school bus routes and at various school locations on three different days of the week: Wednesdays beginning at 7:30am, Thursdays beginning at 8:30am, and Fridays beginning at 9:30am. Please note the day and time that a site or school bus stop near you is serving, and plan to pick up there. Families will be able to pick up a box of meals for five days, including breakfasts and lunches for each school-aged child in their household. You can review all sites and routes by visiting www.spps.org/ns.

For REA Students, the closest pick-ups are at Creative Arts Secondary or Humboldt Senior High, both on Thursdays at 8:30am. You are welcome to pick up at any St. Paul Public school bus stop location if you know of one, but that information is currently not mapped out for the public.

Our staff are currently reaching out to individual families to determine resource and communication needs during this time. We are working to ensure every student has access to learning materials to be successful in school in the case of distance learning, and staff will communicate directly with your family to provide needed supplies and resources as needed. We will provide updates through multiple means of communication to ensure all our families receive needed information.

REA students will be required to check their school email several times a week, and can check their grades and attendance in Infinite Campus as always. Please reach out to Ava to abuchanan@reamn.org or 651-225-9177 x3006 if you cannot login to one or both of those accounts.

REA students will have a grace period to finish work from Quarter 3, which will now end on April 3rd. Students have the option to use the week of spring break (the week of March 23rd) to complete unfinished work or work on their final products. They can email their teachers, as usual, for support with this work. However, students are not expected to complete school work until March 30th when school resumes.
div.h3: What should families and students be doing now?
div.p: SPCS Primary and Middle School families, if you have not spoken with a staff member about communication and access to resources, please email Ka at kvang@stpaulcityschool.org or Vickie at vfranco@stpaulcityschool.org. You may also call the school directly at 651-225-9177. REA families, please email Esteban at erodruiguezhefty@reamn.org or Ava at abuchanan@reamn.org / 651-225-9177 x3006.

Continue to monitor your email, messages, and other means of receiving communication from us each day. We will be providing ongoing updates about remote learning and resources. Please let us know if you have changes to your contact information.

If someone in your home has a fever, cough, or respiratory symptoms or has had these symptoms within the last 24 hours, they should stay home, avoid interacting with others, and you should seek guidance from a medical professional such as your primary care provider. Current recommendations state that you should not go to the ER or clinic locations without being directed to by a COVID19 triage service. Anyone can access free consultation and triage to appropriate medical services in the following ways:

li.p: Online symptom screening, recommendations, and referral with co-pays and out-of-pocket expenses currently waived for COVID-19 and Upper Respiratory Infection visits at www.OnCare.org.

div.p: The Minnesota Department of Health is providing up-to-date and accurate information on recommendations and resources: www.health.state.mn.us/diseases/coronoavirus/action.html

As we continue to receive information about returning to school via distance learning or in-person, we will communicate with you via auto-call, notes home, email, and Facebook page. Do not hesitate to reach out to us in the meantime with any questions or needs.

We are staying up to date with the current response recommendations from the Minnesota Department of Health and the Department of Education. They have been holding regular conference calls with school leaders to keep us informed about the spread of the disease and best practice recommendations. The most recent conference call was this morning and we would like to start this letter by sharing with you what we learned.

li.p: The current goal is to slow down the spread of the disease. The Department of Health recommends several school practices to support community mitigation and we will outline these practices and SPCS action steps below.
The Department of Health is NOT recommending school closures at this time for several reasons:
People age 19 and under are at the lowest risk of disease
Students rely on schools for many resources, including education, meals, health supports, and other services. When school is closed, they cannot as easily access these resources.
The most important steps of community mitigation are quality handwashing and staying home when sick. These have a much higher effective rate than school closure.

div.p: SPCS is taking steps to ensure we are in alignment with recommendations from the Department of Health.

li.p: We are widely sharing and encouraging students to follow the CDC’s recommendations to wash hands for 20-30 seconds, avoid touching your face, and staying home when sick.
Building surfaces are being thoroughly sanitized daily by staff.
We have hired professional cleaners to do a detailed sanitization of all school surfaces during our Spring Break.

div.p: If your child has a fever, cough, or respiratory symptoms or has had these symptoms within the last 24 hours, they are required to stay home. We will ask you to immediately pick your child up and take them home if they become sick at school.
In the event we are required to close, we will communicate with you via autocall, notes home, email, and Facebook page. Do not hesitate to reach out to us in the meantime with any questions or needs.
